title: List of kings of the Lombards
text:
The Kings of the Lombards or reges Langobardorum (singular "rex Langobardorum") were the monarchs of the <a href="Lombards">Lombard people</a> from the early 6th century until the Lombardic identity became lost in the 9th and 10th centuries. After 568, the Lombard kings sometimes styled themselves <a href="King%20of%20Italy">Kings of Italy</a> ("rex totius Italiae"). After 774, they were not Lombards, but <a href="Franks">Franks</a>. From the 12th century, the <a href="votive%20crown">votive crown</a> and <a href="reliquary">reliquary</a> known as the <a href="Iron%20Crown%20of%20Lombardy">Iron Crown</a> ("Corona Ferrea") retrospectively became a symbol of their rule, though it was never used by Lombard kings.
The primary sources for the Lombard kings before the Frankish conquest are the anonymous 7th-century "<a href="Origo%20Gentis%20Langobardorum">Origo Gentis Langobardorum</a>" and the 8th-century "<a href="Historia%20Langobardorum">Historia Langobardorum</a>" of <a href="Paul%20the%20Deacon">Paul the Deacon</a>. The earliest kings (the pre-Lethings) listed in the "Origo" are almost certainly legendary. They purportedly reigned during the <a href="Migration%20Period">Migration Period</a>. The first ruler attested independently of Lombard tradition is Tato.
Early rulers.
<a href="Lething%20Dynasty">Lething Dynasty</a>.
The Lethings were an early dynasty from the time of Lethuc. The last ruling descendant of Lethuc was <a href="Walthari">Walthari</a>, whose son was in turn displaced by <a href="Audoin">Audoin</a> of the family of the Gausi.
Kings in Italy.
<a href="Carolingian%20Dynasty">Carolingian Dynasty</a>.
Charlemagne conquered the Lombards in 774 at the invitation of <a href="Pope%20Adrian%20I">Pope Adrian I</a>.
The title "rex Langobardorum", synonymous with "rex Italiae", lasted well into the <a href="High%20Middle%20Ages">High Middle Ages</a>, but subsequent holders are found at <a href="King%20of%20Italy">King of Italy</a>.
Family tree.
